<ce:section-title id="st055">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0075" view="all">Three POM-based MOFs containing 1D to 3D Ag/3-pttz coordination polymers were successfully synthesized by changing kinds of inorganic salt which containing the center element of the Keggin heteropolymolybdate and pH values.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0055">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
Three POM-based MOFs containing 1D to 3D Ag/3-pttz coordination polymers were successfully synthesized by changing kinds of inorganic salt which containing the center element of the Keggin heteropolymolybdate and pH values.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0055">

elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Three new polyoxometalate-based metal–organic framework compounds [Ag7(3-pttz)4(PMo12O40)]·H2O(1), [Ag6(3-Hpttz)2(3-pttz)2(SiMo12O40)(H2O)2]·2H2O(2) and [Ag6(3-Hpttz)6(PMo12O40)2]·2H2O(3) (3-Hpttz=5-(3-Pyridyl)-1H-tetrazole) are synthesized hydrothermally by changing the polyoxoanions and the pH values in the same metal–organic system (Ag/pttz), and structurally characterized by IR spectra, elemental analyses and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 exhibits a three-dimensional (3D) Ag/3-pttz host framework with larger channels. The discrete [PMo12O40]3− anions, acting as inorganic templates, are embedded in the channels. In compound 2, the Ag/3-pttz motif displays a two-dimensional (2D) stair-like layer, which is linked by [SiMo12O40]4− anions to construct a 3D framework. In compound 3, the Ag/3-pttz motif shows a 1D ribbon-like chain, some of [PMo12O40]3− anions in a “shoulder-to-shoulder” mode link two ribbon-like polymers to form a 1D “quadrangular prism-like” chains, and the others of [PMo12O40]3− anions bond to chains and become pendants of the quadrangular prism, projecting toward two sides. Therefore, compound 3 displays a scarce 1D “quadrangular prism with pendants” structure. In addition, the electrochemical behavior and electrocatalytic activity of compound 1 as an example were investigated.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The designs and syntheses of polyoxometalate-based (POM) metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention in the field of materials chemistry and crystal engineering owing to their potential applications in catalysis, medicine, nanotechnology, as well as their fascinating architectures and topological frameworks . The reported works indicate that polyoxometalates are a kind of multiple functional metal oxide clusters in the crystal engineering of POM-based MOFs. Firstly, they are multidentate inorganic ligands due to their larger size and multiple coordination sites, so they can connect more than one metal cation to form high-connected and high dimensional POM-based MOFs. Secondly, POMs can control and adjust the sizes, shapes and dimensions of MOFs due to their various sizes, shapes, electronic density, and oxo-rich surfaces. Furthermore, MOFs can also conquer the inherent drawbacks of POMs (such as low specific surface area and instability under the reaction conditions) to optimize the traditional POM materials. The introduction of POM building blocks to MOF is not merely a strategy to obtain charming structures, but also an effective method to construct multifunctional hybrid materials .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
The designs and syntheses of polyoxometalate-based (POM) metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention in the field of materials chemistry and crystal engineering owing to their potential applications in catalysis, medicine, nanotechnology, as well as their fascinating architectures and topological frameworks . The reported works indicate that polyoxometalates are a kind of multiple functional metal oxide clusters in the crystal engineering of POM-based MOFs. Firstly, they are multidentate inorganic ligands due to their larger size and multiple coordination sites, so they can connect more than one metal cation to form high-connected and high dimensional POM-based MOFs. Secondly, POMs can control and adjust the sizes, shapes and dimensions of MOFs due to their various sizes, shapes, electronic density, and oxo-rich surfaces. Furthermore, MOFs can also conquer the inherent drawbacks of POMs (such as low specific surface area and instability under the reaction conditions) to optimize the traditional POM materials. The introduction of POM building blocks to MOF is not merely a strategy to obtain charming structures, but also an effective method to construct multifunctional hybrid materials .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The final structures of POM-based MOFs are commonly influenced by various factors, such as pH value in the reaction, coordination geometries of metal ions, electronic charge, sizes and shapes of POMs and coordination modes, steric hindrance, and flexibility of ligands. Therefore, from the crystal engineering point of view, the rational design and control of self assembly processes is still a very challenging work to realize the targeted syntheses of POM-based MOFs. The rigid ligand 5-(3-pyridyl)-1H-tetrazole (3-Hpttz) in its anionic form is an attractive multidentate ligand for the design of POM-based MOFs owning to their smaller steric hindrance, more donor atoms and flexible coordinate modes (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>). So it is a good candidate for acting as useful organic linkers for the connection of the POM units . Additionally, a rational selection of the metal centers is also crucial. The silver ion can display various coordination geometries including linear, T-type, Y-type, “seesaw”, “square pyramidal” and “trigonal bipyramidal” . Therefore, it fits into the abundant coordination mode of the 3-Hpttz ligand and can be chosen as the bridging linker in POM-based MOFs . Among the different types of POMs, the Keggin POMs, have widely been regarded as an important molecular building unit for constructing inorganic–organic coordination polymers due to its unique structure and electronic characteristics .</ce:para>

The silver ion can display various coordination geometries including linear, T-type, Y-type, “seesaw”, “square pyramidal” and “trigonal bipyramidal” . Therefore, it fits into the abundant coordination mode of the 3-Hpttz ligand and can be chosen as the bridging linker in POM-based MOFs . elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Considering aforementioned points, we selected Keggin POMs, transition metal Ag(I) cation, and organic ligand 3-Hpttz to construct the POMs-based MOFs in different pH value. As expected, three new compounds were obtained: [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(3-Hpttz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SiMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(3-Hpttz)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), (3-Hpttz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-(3-Pyridyl)-1H-tetrazole). Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> provide good examples of reasonable design and controllable assembly of POM-based coordination polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Considering aforementioned points, we selected Keggin POMs, transition metal Ag(I) cation, and organic ligand 3-Hpttz to construct the POMs-based MOFs in different pH value. As expected, three new compounds were obtained: [Ag7(3-pttz)4(PMo12O40)2]·H2O(1), [Ag6(3-Hpttz)2(3-pttz)2(SiMo12O40)(H2O)2]·2H2O(2), [Ag6(3-Hpttz)6(PMo12O40)2]·2H2O(3), (3-Hpttz=5-(3-Pyridyl)-1H-tetrazole). Compounds 1, 2 and 3 provide good examples of reasonable design and controllable assembly of POM-based coordination polymers.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st015">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">5-(3-Pyridyl)-1H-tetrazole (abbreviated as 3-Hpttz) was prepared according to literature procedures . All reagents for the syntheses were purchased from commercial and used as received. All title compounds were synthesized in poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel autoclaves under autogenous pressure. Elemental analyses of C, H and N were performed with an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. IR (KBr pellet) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 750FTIR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a METTLER TGA/SDTA851 microanalyzer under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku DMAX2500 powder diffractometer at 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV and 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mA using Cu Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.54056<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Cyclic voltammetry measurements were carried out on a CHI 660B electrochemical station using a conventional three-electrode single compartment cell at room temperature. The working electrode was a modified CPE (carbon paste electrode). Platinum gauze was used as the counter electrode and Ag/AgCl was used as the reference electrode. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-modified carbon paste electrode (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE) was fabricated as follows: 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg of graphite powder and 65<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were mixed, and ground together by an agate mortar and pestle to achieve an even, dry mixture. Paraffin oil (0.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was then added to the mixture and stirred. The mixture was further packed into a graphite tube (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm inner diameter).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and methods
5-(3-Pyridyl)-1H-tetrazole (abbreviated as 3-Hpttz) was prepared according to literature procedures . All reagents for the syntheses were purchased from commercial and used as received. All title compounds were synthesized in poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel autoclaves under autogenous pressure. Elemental analyses of C, H and N were performed with an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. IR (KBr pellet) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 750FTIR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a METTLER TGA/SDTA851 microanalyzer under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku DMAX2500 powder diffractometer at 40kV and 100mA using Cu Kα radiation (λ
=1.54056Å). Cyclic voltammetry measurements were carried out on a CHI 660B electrochemical station using a conventional three-electrode single compartment cell at room temperature. The working electrode was a modified CPE (carbon paste electrode). Platinum gauze was used as the counter electrode and Ag/AgCl was used as the reference electrode. Compound 1-modified carbon paste electrode (1-CPE) was fabricated as follows: 600mg of graphite powder and 65mg compound 1 were mixed, and ground together by an agate mortar and pestle to achieve an even, dry mixture. Paraffin oil (0.7mL) was then added to the mixture and stirred. The mixture was further packed into a graphite tube (3mm inner diameter).

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of compounds 1–3

[Ag7(3-pttz)4(PMo12O40)]·H2O(1)
A mixture of MoO3 (0.8mmol), AgNO3 (0.3mmol), 3-Hpttz (0.2mmol), KH2PO4 (0.1mmol) was dissolved in 8.0mL of HNO3 aqueous solution (0.25M) and stirred for half an hour at the pH value of 2.3. Then the mixture was sealed in an 18ml Teflon-lined reactor and heated at 165°C for 3days. Yellow columnar crystals of compound 1 were obtained, filtered, washed with water and dried at room temperature (yield: ∼50% based on Mo). Anal. Calc. for C24H18Ag7Mo12N20O41P: C, 9.06; H, 0.57; N, 8.81. Found: C, 8.89; H, 0.66; N, 8.96%. IR (solid KBr pellet, v/cm−1): 3443(m), 1608(m), 1454(m), 1424(m), 1386(m), 1061(vs), 956(vs), 875(vs), 795(vs), 674(s), 499(s).

<ce:section-title id="st025">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were carried out on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature. Structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by using the <ce:small-caps>shelx</ce:small-caps>-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were located with successive Fourier difference syntheses and refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were generated geometrically (C–H, 0.93<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). For the compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the hydrogen atoms attached to water molecules were located in difference Fourier map. But the water H atoms of compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were not located. A summary of crystallographic data and other pertinent information for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is provided in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in . Weak coordination interactions [Ag–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.634–2.862<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] are observed within the title compounds. The weak coordination bonds are also discussed in extending the dimensionality of compounds. Consequently, they are listed in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of 1–3 were carried out on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ
=0.71073Å) at room temperature. Structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F
2 by using the shelx-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were located with successive Fourier difference syntheses and refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were generated geometrically (C–H, 0.93Å). For the compounds 1, the hydrogen atoms attached to water molecules were located in difference Fourier map. But the water H atoms of compounds 2 and 3 were not located. A summary of crystallographic data and other pertinent information for 1–3 is provided in 
. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in . Weak coordination interactions [Ag–O=2.634–2.862Å] are observed within the title compounds. The weak coordination bonds are also discussed in extending the dimensionality of compounds. Consequently, they are listed in .

<ce:section-title id="st030">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Description of the crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was obtained at the pH value of 2.6. Crystallographic structure analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a) is made up of seven Ag ions, four 3-pttz ligands, one PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> polyoxoanion and one water molecule. Seven crystallographically independent Ag(I) ions adopt four kinds of coordination geometries: (i) The Ag3, Ag5 and Ag6 ions are coordinated in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, among which Ag3 is coordinated by two N atoms (N10, N11B) from two pttz ligands and two O atoms (O11J, O17J) from the PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> polyoxoanion, Ag5 is achieved by four N atoms (N3D, N6C, N15, N18) of four 3-pttz ligands, Ag6 is bound to three N atoms (N2D, N12E, N19) from 3-pttz ligands, one O atom (O41C) from water molecule. (ii) The Ag1 exhibits a square planar geometry defined by two N atoms from two 3-pttz ligands and two O atoms from two PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> clusters. (iii) The Ag4 and Ag7 ions adopt a three-coordinated “Y-shaped” geometry, realized by three N atoms from three 3-pttz. (iv) The Ag2 ion is coordinated by N5 and N16 atoms from a 3-pttz ligand in a linear geometry. Additionally, each PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> cluster acts as a tetra-dentate inorganic ligand coordinating to three silver centers (b). The 3-pttz ligands exhibit two intriguing coordination modes: (1) it utilizes all of its five N donors to link five silver atoms, acting as a pentadentate bridging ligand (1-type in ); (2) it acts as a tetra-dentate linkage, bridging three Ag (I) ions through three adjacent N atoms from tetrazolyl group and one N atom from pyridyl groups (2-type in ). These coordination features of 3-pttz ligands in which the 3-pyridyl groups take part in coordination help expand the dimensionality of MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Description of the crystal structures
Compound 1 was obtained at the pH value of 2.6. Crystallographic structure analysis reveals that compound 1 (
a) is made up of seven Ag ions, four 3-pttz ligands, one PMo12 polyoxoanion and one water molecule. Seven crystallographically independent Ag(I) ions adopt four kinds of coordination geometries: (i) The Ag3, Ag5 and Ag6 ions are coordinated in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, among which Ag3 is coordinated by two N atoms (N10, N11B) from two pttz ligands and two O atoms (O11J, O17J) from the PMo12 polyoxoanion, Ag5 is achieved by four N atoms (N3D, N6C, N15, N18) of four 3-pttz ligands, Ag6 is bound to three N atoms (N2D, N12E, N19) from 3-pttz ligands, one O atom (O41C) from water molecule. (ii) The Ag1 exhibits a square planar geometry defined by two N atoms from two 3-pttz ligands and two O atoms from two PMo12 clusters. (iii) The Ag4 and Ag7 ions adopt a three-coordinated “Y-shaped” geometry, realized by three N atoms from three 3-pttz. (iv) The Ag2 ion is coordinated by N5 and N16 atoms from a 3-pttz ligand in a linear geometry. Additionally, each PMo12 cluster acts as a tetra-dentate inorganic ligand coordinating to three silver centers (b). The 3-pttz ligands exhibit two intriguing coordination modes: (1) it utilizes all of its five N donors to link five silver atoms, acting as a pentadentate bridging ligand (1-type in ); (2) it acts as a tetra-dentate linkage, bridging three Ag (I) ions through three adjacent N atoms from tetrazolyl group and one N atom from pyridyl groups (2-type in ). These coordination features of 3-pttz ligands in which the 3-pyridyl groups take part in coordination help expand the dimensionality of MOFs.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a 3D [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> host framework with larger channels. The discrete PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> clusters as templates are cemented into the channels. The host [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> MOF is divided into two moieties. One is a 2D layer formed by Ag3 ions and tetra-nuclear [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] subunits, in which [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] is constructed from three types of 3-pttz ligands, Ag4, Ag5, Ag6 and Ag7 ions (a). The adjacent tetra-nuclear subunits are fused together by Ag7–N8, Ag7–N13 and Ag6–N12 bonds in a hand by hand mode, generating an infinite organic–inorganic chain (A-type) along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis (b). These parallel chains are further connected together by Ag3 ions and Ag5-N6 bond leading to a stair-like 2D MOF (c). The other moiety is the infinite [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3-pttz)] chains (B-type) constructed by Ag1, Ag2 and one 3-pttz ligand (d). The [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3-pttz)] chains connect adjacent layers <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> Ag2–N16, Ag6–N2 and Ag5–N3 bonds to form open 3D metal–organic host framework with the larger pores (ca. 9.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), as shown in e. The guest PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> clusters as templates occupy the large channels. From the topological view, if PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> are considered as three-connected nodes, Ag3 ions as three-connected nodes, A-type chains subunits as eight-connected nodes and B-type chains subunits as six-connected nodes, the interconnection of alternating two subunits, Ag3 and PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> results in an infinite 3D (3,3,6,8)-connected 4-nodal net (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>) with the point symbol {4.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.5}{4<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>.7}{4<ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">11</ce:sup>.7}, which represents a new topology analyzed by the topos 4.0 program.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained by the same procedure as <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> except that Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SiO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was used instead of KH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">4.</ce:inf> It also exhibits a 3D framework, which is constructed from the 2D [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> MOF through covalently connected discrete SiMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> polyoxoanions (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). The similar structure has been found in the reported compound [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(ptz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][HPMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . Evidently, they have a same 2D [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> organic-metal framework, but different types of polyoxoanions (PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf> for compound reported , and SiMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> for title compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Each Keggin polyoxoanion acts as a tetra-dentate inorganic ligand coordinating to six silver centers in two compounds (). The 3-Hpttz ligands adopt the two different coordination modes (1-type and 3-type in ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Compound 2 was obtained by the same procedure as 1 except that Na2SiO3 was used instead of KH2PO4. It also exhibits a 3D framework, which is constructed from the 2D [Ag3(3-pttz)2]+ MOF through covalently connected discrete SiMo12 polyoxoanions (
). The similar structure has been found in the reported compound [Ag6(ptz)4(H2O)2][HPMo12O40]·3H2O . Evidently, they have a same 2D [Ag3(3-pttz)2]+ organic-metal framework, but different types of polyoxoanions (PMo12O40 for compound reported , and SiMo12 for title compound 2). Each Keggin polyoxoanion acts as a tetra-dentate inorganic ligand coordinating to six silver centers in two compounds (). The 3-Hpttz ligands adopt the two different coordination modes (1-type and 3-type in ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was prepared by the similar procedure as compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> except that the pH value of the reaction was decreased to about 1.1. But the remarkably different structure was found in compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. It consists of six Ag ions, six 3-pttz ligands, two PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> polyoxoanions and four water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>a). The six crystallographically independent Ag cations exhibit two sorts of coordination geometries. Ag1, Ag2 and Ag6 centers show similar tetrahedral geometry coordination, which are coordinated by three N atoms from three 3-pttz ligands and one terminal oxygen atom from the PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> anion, respectively. Ag3, Ag4 and Ag5 are three-coordinated in a “Y-type” geometry completed by three N atoms from three 3-pttz ligands. Two PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> polyoxoanions all exhibit a classical α-Keggin configuration. The central atom P of one polyoxoanion (PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">a</ce:sup>) is four coordinated in a tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by four oxygen atoms, while that of the other polyoxoanion (PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">b</ce:sup>) is disordered surrounded by a cube of eight oxygen atoms with each oxygen site half occupied. The two kinds of PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> anions adopt an asymmetrical coordination mode. The PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">a</ce:sup> cluster acts as a bidentate inorganic ligand bridging two crystallographically independent Ag ions with two terminal O atoms, while the PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">b</ce:sup> cluster acts as a monodentate ligand coordinating to one Ag ion with bridge oxygen atom (b). The 3-pttz ligands show three different coordination modes (4-type, 5-type and 6-type in ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Compound 3 was prepared by the similar procedure as compound 1 except that the pH value of the reaction was decreased to about 1.1. But the remarkably different structure was found in compound 3. It consists of six Ag ions, six 3-pttz ligands, two PMo12 polyoxoanions and four water molecules (
a). The six crystallographically independent Ag cations exhibit two sorts of coordination geometries. Ag1, Ag2 and Ag6 centers show similar tetrahedral geometry coordination, which are coordinated by three N atoms from three 3-pttz ligands and one terminal oxygen atom from the PMo12 anion, respectively. Ag3, Ag4 and Ag5 are three-coordinated in a “Y-type” geometry completed by three N atoms from three 3-pttz ligands. Two PMo12 polyoxoanions all exhibit a classical α-Keggin configuration. The central atom P of one polyoxoanion (PMo12
a) is four coordinated in a tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by four oxygen atoms, while that of the other polyoxoanion (PMo12
b) is disordered surrounded by a cube of eight oxygen atoms with each oxygen site half occupied. The two kinds of PMo12 anions adopt an asymmetrical coordination mode. The PMo12
a cluster acts as a bidentate inorganic ligand bridging two crystallographically independent Ag ions with two terminal O atoms, while the PMo12
b cluster acts as a monodentate ligand coordinating to one Ag ion with bridge oxygen atom (b). The 3-pttz ligands show three different coordination modes (4-type, 5-type and 6-type in ).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">It is worth noting that three compounds show completely different POM-based MOFs structures, in which the Ag/3-pttz MOFs also exhibit different extended structure. In compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Ag/3-pttz MOF displays a 3D [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> host structure with channels. In compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, it exhibits a 2D [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(3-Hpttz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> stair-like layers obtained by changing kinds of inorganic salts containing the center element of the Keggin heteropolymolybdate. While it shows a 1D [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(3-Hpttz)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">6+</ce:sup> ribbon-like chain in compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> synthesized by decreasing pH values in the reaction. The obvious difference between compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> indicates that the coordination ability of Keggin-type POMs and 3-pttz could be enhanced by increasing pH values. Because of the increase in the pH value, the ligands and PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> do not combine with H<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> but coordinate with more metal ions to form high dimensional coordination polymers . Moreover, the differences in electronic charge of the two kinds of polyoxoanions in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be a impact factor to result in distinctive MOFs of Ag/pttz.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is worth noting that three compounds show completely different POM-based MOFs structures, in which the Ag/3-pttz MOFs also exhibit different extended structure. In compound 1, the Ag/3-pttz MOF displays a 3D [Ag7(3-pttz)4]3+ host structure with channels. In compound 2, it exhibits a 2D [Ag6(3-Hpttz)2(3-pttz)2]4+ stair-like layers obtained by changing kinds of inorganic salts containing the center element of the Keggin heteropolymolybdate. While it shows a 1D [Ag6(3-Hpttz)6]6+ ribbon-like chain in compound 3 synthesized by decreasing pH values in the reaction. The obvious difference between compound 1 and compound 3 indicates that the coordination ability of Keggin-type POMs and 3-pttz could be enhanced by increasing pH values. Because of the increase in the pH value, the ligands and PMo12 in 3 do not combine with H+ but coordinate with more metal ions to form high dimensional coordination polymers . Moreover, the differences in electronic charge of the two kinds of polyoxoanions in compound 2 and 1 may be a impact factor to result in distinctive MOFs of Ag/pttz.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st040">Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and TG analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The PXRD patterns for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are presented in , respectively. The diffraction peaks of both simulated and experimental patterns match well, indicating high purities of the compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and the experimental patterns is due to the different orientation of the crystals in the powder samples.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and TG analyses
The PXRD patterns for 1, 2 and 3 are presented in , respectively. The diffraction peaks of both simulated and experimental patterns match well, indicating high purities of the compounds 1, 2 and 3, respectively. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and the experimental patterns is due to the different orientation of the crystals in the powder samples.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Thermogravimetric experiments of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were performed to evaluate their thermal stabilities, and the resulting curves are shown in , respectively. The TG curves of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are similar, and they both exhibit a three-step weight loss. The first weight losses of 0.50% (calcd. 0.57%) in 40–220<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, 2.27% (calcd. 2.30%) in 45–210<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 0.64% (calcd. 0.69%) in 45–220<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C are attributed to the release of crystalline water for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively. while the following two weight losses of about 18.96% (calcd. 18.38%) in 290–670<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 18.28% (cacld. 18.77%) in 330–630<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and 16.97% (cacld. 17.64%) in 285–680<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are respectively attributed to the decomposition of 3-pttz ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric experiments of compounds 1, 2 and 3 were performed to evaluate their thermal stabilities, and the resulting curves are shown in , respectively. The TG curves of 1, 2 and 3 are similar, and they both exhibit a three-step weight loss. The first weight losses of 0.50% (calcd. 0.57%) in 40–220°C, 2.27% (calcd. 2.30%) in 45–210°C and 0.64% (calcd. 0.69%) in 45–220°C are attributed to the release of crystalline water for compounds 1, 2 and 3, respectively. while the following two weight losses of about 18.96% (calcd. 18.38%) in 290–670°C for 1, 18.28% (cacld. 18.77%) in 330–630°C for 2 and 16.97% (cacld. 17.64%) in 285–680°C for 3 are respectively attributed to the decomposition of 3-pttz ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st045">Cyclic voltammetric behavior</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Cyclic voltammetric behavior of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> as an example was investigated. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor> (a) shows the cyclic voltammetric behavior of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE in the 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol·L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol·L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> aqueous solution. It can be seen that there are three redox peaks (I−I′, II−II′, III−III′) in the potential range from −200 to +600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV (scan rate: 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV·s<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). The mean peak potentials E<ce:inf loc="post">1/</ce:inf>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(E<ce:inf loc="post">pc</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>E<ce:inf loc="post">pa</ce:inf>)/2 are 349.5, 199.5, and −35.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV, respectively, which should be ascribed to three consecutive two-electron processes of Mo<ce:sup loc="post">VI</ce:sup> ion . As shown in (b), the peak potentials change gradually following the scan rate from 20 to 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV·s<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>: the cathodic peak potentials shift to the negative direction and the corresponding anodic peak potentials to the positive direction. The peak-to-peak separation between the corresponding cathodic and anodic peaks increases with the scan rate increasing, but the mean peak potentials does not change on the whole. It indicates that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be used as a potential electrocatalyst in solutions owning to its good electrochemical activity. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor> shows the corresponding cyclic voltammograms for the electrocatalytic reduction of NaNO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and NaBrO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> by <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE in the 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol·L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol·L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> solution, respectively. It can be seen that, with increasing the concentration of NaNO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and NaBrO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, the reduction peak currents increase gradually and the corresponding oxidation peak currents decrease gradually. This clearly indicates that the NaNO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and NaBrO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> are electrocatalytically reduced by the [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE. In other words, the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits effective electrocatalytic activity for the reduction of NaNO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and NaBrO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cyclic voltammetric behavior
Cyclic voltammetric behavior of compound 1 as an example was investigated. 
 (a) shows the cyclic voltammetric behavior of 1-CPE in the 0.25mol·L−1 Na2SO4
+0.5mol·L−1 H2SO4 aqueous solution. It can be seen that there are three redox peaks (I−I′, II−II′, III−III′) in the potential range from −200 to +600mV (scan rate: 100mV·s−1). The mean peak potentials E1/
2
=(Epc
+Epa)/2 are 349.5, 199.5, and −35.5mV, respectively, which should be ascribed to three consecutive two-electron processes of MoVI ion . As shown in (b), the peak potentials change gradually following the scan rate from 20 to 200mV·s−1: the cathodic peak potentials shift to the negative direction and the corresponding anodic peak potentials to the positive direction. The peak-to-peak separation between the corresponding cathodic and anodic peaks increases with the scan rate increasing, but the mean peak potentials does not change on the whole. It indicates that compound 1 can be used as a potential electrocatalyst in solutions owning to its good electrochemical activity. 
 shows the corresponding cyclic voltammograms for the electrocatalytic reduction of NaNO2 and NaBrO3 by 1-CPE in the 0.25mol·L−1 Na2SO4
+0.5mol·L−1 H2SO4 and 1mol·L−1 Na2SO4
+1mol·L−1 H2SO4 solution, respectively. It can be seen that, with increasing the concentration of NaNO2 and NaBrO3, the reduction peak currents increase gradually and the corresponding oxidation peak currents decrease gradually. This clearly indicates that the NaNO2 and NaBrO3 are electrocatalytically reduced by the [Ag7(3-pttz)4(PMo12O40)2]·H2O in 1-CPE. In other words, the compound 1 exhibits effective electrocatalytic activity for the reduction of NaNO2 and NaBrO3.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st050">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">In this study, by utilizing Ag ions and 3-Hpttz ligands with diverse coordination modes as building elements and Keggin POMs as templates, three POM-based MOFs containing different dimensional Ag/3-pttz framework were successfully synthesized under different hydrothermal conditions. Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses a 3D framework assembled by discrete PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> clusters and a 3D [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> host MOF with channels. The PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> anions as templates direct the formation of the 3D [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> host MOF and locate in the channels. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, featuring 3D framework composed of the adjacent [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(3-Hpttz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3-pttz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> stair-like layers linked by SiMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> anions, was obtained by changing kinds of inorganic salt which containing the center element of the Keggin heteropolymolybdate and pH values. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, with a scarce 1D “quadrangular prism with pendants” structure was obtained by altering pH values. The [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(3-Hpttz)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">6+</ce:sup> motif shows a 1D ribbon-like chain. PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">a</ce:sup> anions in a ‘‘shoulder-to-shoulder’’ mode links two ribbon-like polymers to form a 1D ‘‘quadrangular prism-like’’ chain. PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">b</ce:sup> clusters bond to chains and become pendants of the quadrangular prism, projecting toward two sides. In conclusion, targeted syntheses of POM-based MOFs materials depend on a synergic effect of suitable choice of POMs, organic ligands, metal ions and fit pH value. Furthermore, the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> bulk-modified carbon-paste electrode (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE) displays good electrocatalytic activity toward the reduction of nitrite and bromate, showing compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has potential application in electrocatalysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In this study, by utilizing Ag ions and 3-Hpttz ligands with diverse coordination modes as building elements and Keggin POMs as templates, three POM-based MOFs containing different dimensional Ag/3-pttz framework were successfully synthesized under different hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1 possesses a 3D framework assembled by discrete PMo12 clusters and a 3D [Ag7(3-pttz)4]3+ host MOF with channels. The PMo12 anions as templates direct the formation of the 3D [Ag7(3-pttz)4]]3+ host MOF and locate in the channels. Compound 2, featuring 3D framework composed of the adjacent [Ag6(3-Hpttz)2(3-pttz)2]4+ stair-like layers linked by SiMo12 anions, was obtained by changing kinds of inorganic salt which containing the center element of the Keggin heteropolymolybdate and pH values. Compound 3, with a scarce 1D “quadrangular prism with pendants” structure was obtained by altering pH values. The [Ag6(3-Hpttz)6]6+ motif shows a 1D ribbon-like chain. PMo12
a anions in a ‘‘shoulder-to-shoulder’’ mode links two ribbon-like polymers to form a 1D ‘‘quadrangular prism-like’’ chain. PMo12
b clusters bond to chains and become pendants of the quadrangular prism, projecting toward two sides. In conclusion, targeted syntheses of POM-based MOFs materials depend on a synergic effect of suitable choice of POMs, organic ligands, metal ions and fit pH value. Furthermore, the compound 1 bulk-modified carbon-paste electrode (1-CPE) displays good electrocatalytic activity toward the reduction of nitrite and bromate, showing compound 1 has potential application in electrocatalysis.
